III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS & CONCLUSIONS
a. Physical Description of Facility
Gail’s House was formerly licensed as the Child Caring Institution “Gail’s House
(CI390201232)”. “Gail’s House” requested a change in their license (CCI to TCCI) to
reflect the change in their program services. Gail’s House is located on the east side of
Kalamazoo, in a mixed residential and industrial setting. The home is a single story
3,300 square foot brick structure that appears to be in very good condition. The facility
was built in 1993 and has six individual bedrooms. The bedrooms are located near the
two common bathrooms, laundry room and have a small common area where staff will
be stationed during the evening hours. The smaller common area is connected to the
larger common area by a short hallway. Within the rest of the structure, there is a large
common area that serves as a recreational, dining, and social area. Located next to the
large common area is the kitchen which has a partial wall providing a line of sight into
the common area. Also connected to this large common area is the staff office and staff
bathroom. Another hallway leads from the large common area to a door leading to the
attached 500 square foot two vehicle garage. The garage is used as an activity space.
Just before the door to the garage is a storage room. There are two emergency exits in
the house, one in the bedroom area and the other at the other end of the building.
Outside of the home is a fenced in playground area. The Fire Inspection was completed
with an “A” rating on December 14, 2016 and the Environmental Health Inspection was
completed with an “A” rating on November 28, 2016.
b. Program Description
Gail’s House will provide short-term residential services for residents who have a
primary mental health diagnosis and are experiencing an acute psychiatric crisis. This
treatment program is intended to provide short term care as an alternative to inpatient
psychiatric services or to avert an inpatient psychiatric admission. The focus will be on
providing a temporary separation from the resident’s natural environment to prevent the
risk of deterioration of their mental health condition or harm to themselves or others.
2

Gail’s House will provide residential services to both genders of residents, covering
age’s five to seventeen. The program will be licensed to provide care for six residents at
a time, and the assessment process will focus on keeping residents in the program that
are in the same developmental age range. The agency believes that given the nature of
the program, their primary referrals with be older residents with the occasional sibling
group involving younger ages. The initial assessment will be used to screen the age
range of the resident with a focus on accepting those of a similar developmental age
range. The focus for the agency will be to only accept those residents of a similar
developmental age range and similar presenting problem issues. The agency will not
mix populations of different developmental age ranges, given the difficulties that would
be presented with the supervision of multiple developmental age ranges. If the agency
encounters a referral involving a sibling group with a wide developmental age range,
then the appropriate staffing model will be made available. This might involve on-on-one
supervision for the younger resident with a more basic supervision ratio for the older
resident. This situation is considered to be unlikely since the agency will be screening
potential residents at the initial assessment. The general length of stay can vary and
may range from forty-eight hours of respite to several days, depending on the needs of
the resident, parent, and situation surrounding the referral. Crisis residential stays may
not exceed fourteen nights and will typically last two to fourteen days. The program is
designed to treat residents with behaviors that are difficult to manage or that require
constant supervision. These behaviors are described as; verbally aggressive, property
destructive, noncompliance, withdrawal, and inappropriate or a lack of social skills. The
program is also designed to help residents experiencing a Serious Emotional
disturbance (SED), having a possible diagnosis of Developmental Disability (DD), and
suffering unspecified trauma. The SED resident may be diagnosed with Attention
Deficit-Hyperactivity Disorder, Oppositional Defiant Disorder, Post-Traumatic Stress
Disorder, Depressive Disorder, Anxiety Disorder or Intermittent Explosive Disorder.
Some of the DD diagnoses may include one of the following: Cerebral Palsy, Autism
Spectrum Disorder, or Intellectual Development Disorder. The focus of treatment will be
on providing a safe, nurturing, and structured environment in which the resident can
learn appropriate ways of coping (healing), resolving, and developing methods of
overcoming the challenges that brought them into care. Another focus of treatment is to
offer opportunities for socialization, recreation, and skill enhancement for each resident.
Individualized treatment goals will be determined through the circumstances that
brought the resident into care, the intake assessment, and background information
provided by the parents and the referral source. The resident and parents will both be
involved in the different skills building in an effort to help the resident’s caretaker
understand positive and healthy ways of being a support for the resident. Although the
parent will not be the primary focus, providing them with the necessary knowledge and
tools to cope with the resident is a central focus of the program. Schooling for school
age residents will be provided to the resident if their stay is during a school day.
Education will be provided by the resident’s school, local, or intermediate school district
at established community schools as coordinated by the referring worker. If a resident is
homeschooled, Program staff will work with the resident to complete school work as
directed.
3

The treatment program at Gail’s House utilizes the Positive Behavior Support (PBS)
system, which has a focus of reinforcing a resident’s positive behaviors. This treatment
program also involves engaging the resident in numerous on-site and community
activities (depending on the age and development abilities of the resident). Activities
that are identified are those activities that support the treatment goals and help to build
positive skills within the resident. On-site activities include the “Activity Center”, gym,
and utilizing outdoor space (walking track or basketball court).
Gail’s House treatment team consists of highly trained (licensed where required)
professionals (Program Director, Program Manager, Direct Care Staff Supervisor,
Clinical Staff, Specialists, Support Staff, and Direct Care Staff) with skills in treatment
plan development, de-escalation techniques, crisis intervention, and skills development
for the residents. Each of the treatment staff are required to attend significant training on
different interventions and methods of positive interventions. Staff to resident ratio range
from 1:1 to 1:6 during awake hours with a maximum of 1:6 during sleeping hours.
Staffing ratios will change depending upon the need to ensure adequate supervision,
safety, service quality, and to facilitate positive peer interactions.
Because this program is being licensed as a Therapeutic Group home, the staff is fully
aware that physical management, seclusion, and the use of behavior management
rooms are not allowed. Therefore, the administration of this program is very aware that
teaching appropriate, non- physical intervention techniques is required. The staff will be
provided training in the “Mandt System” which utilizes numerous de-escalation
techniques and non-physical intervention methods. Oversight to the levels of staff is
provided, and team meetings support a strong team approach to providing services to
the resident and their families.
At this time, Gail’s House will receive referrals from two primary sources; Community
Mental Health Services Program and Private Payer.
c. Rule/Statutory Violations
None
IV. RECOMMENDATION
It is recommended that an initial provisional license be issued to this Child Caring
Institution.
